qas.question: An infinite sea of particles with negative energy  was a model propesed by whom?
What year was the Dirac sea modeled?
What year was the uncertainty principle formed?
What theorized that time and energy can be measured?
What kind of energy did Werner Heisenberg believe a vacuum held?
What did Heisenberg call the particles with negative energy inside a vacuum?
What did Heisenberg predict the existence of in 1930?
How long did it take for the uncertainty principle by Dirac to be confirmed?
What in the late 20th century did Dirac theorize can be measured?

context: In <a1_0>1930<a1_0/>, <a0_0>Paul Dirac<a0_0/> proposed a model of the vacuum as an infinite sea of particles possessing <b5_0>negative<b5_0/> energy, called <b6_0>the Dirac sea<b6_0/>. This theory helped refine the predictions of his earlier formulated Dirac equation, and successfully predicted the existence of <b7_0>the positron<b7_0/>, confirmed <b8_0>two years<b8_0/> later. <a4_0>Werner Heisenberg's uncertainty principle<a4_0/> formulated in <a3_0>1927,<a3_0/> predict a fundamental limit within which instantaneous position and momentum, or <b9_0>energy and time<b9_0/> can be measured. This has far reaching consequences on the "emptiness" of space between particles. In the <a2_0>late 20th century<a2_0/>, so-called virtual particles that arise spontaneously from empty space were confirmed.
